question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
Mrs. Sreelakshmi’s / musical intelligence / is superior than / Mrs. Suma’s.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 12-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Correct Answer: is superior than

Explanation: The phrase "superior than" is incorrect. The correct phrase is "superior to", not "superior than."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
No other place in this country is so better as Gulmarg, Kashmir.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 10-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
CorrectAnswer: so better as
Explanation: The phrase "so better as" is grammatically incorrect. The correct form should be "so much better as" or simply "better than," as comparisons involving adjectives like "better" do not require "so better as.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Rahul thinks he is as smarter as his friends in the class.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 11-Sep Shift 2)
option_2: he is as smarter as
solution:
Correct Answer: he is as smarter as

Explanation:

The error lies in the incorrect use of "as smarter as." The correct construction for comparison using "as...as" does not include the comparative form of the adjective. It should simply be "as smart as."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Neither my brother nor my brothers-in-law / attended the meeting / as his health is not more good.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 11-Sep Shift 2)
option_2: as his health is not more good
option_4: Neither my brother nor my brothers-in-law
solution:
Correct Answer: as his health is not more good

Explanation:

The phrase "not more good" is incorrect. The correct comparative form of "good" is "better." The corrected sentence should read:
"as his health is not better."

Corrected Sentence:

Neither my brother nor my brothers-in-law attended the meeting as his health is not better.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The tea at this café is best than at the Costa Café in our office.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 09-Sep Shift 3)
option_3: The tea at this café
solution:
Correct Answer: is best than

Explanation:
The phrase "is best than" is incorrect. The correct comparative form should be "is better than." "Best" is the superlative form, which is used when comparing more than two things, while "better" is the correct comparative form for comparing two things.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Please go and meet the chairperson. / She will be / away for the / few next days.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 25-Sep Shift 3)
option_4: Please go and meet the chairperson.
solution:
Correct Answer:few next days.

Explanation: The phrase should be "the next few days" rather than "few next days." The correct order places "the" before "next" and "few" after it.

Other segments are correct:

  • "Please go and meet the chairperson." – Correct sentence.

  • "She will be" – Correct sentence.

  • "Away for the" – Correct sentence.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
She is enough wise not to interfere in their matter, once being insulted publicly by them.

(SSC Selection Post P-12 GL : 26 June Shift-3 GL)
solution:
The part of the sentence that contains an error is:

She is enough wise

The correct expression should be "She is wise enough". In English, the adjective "wise" is followed by "enough" rather than "enough" coming before the adjective.

The corrected sentence should read:
"She is wise enough not to interfere in their matter, once being insulted publicly by them."

question:
Parts of the following sentences have been given as options. Select the option that contains a grammatical error.
Ms. Malathi is living lonely in an apartment.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 27 June Shift-3)
solution:
The phrase "lonely in" is incorrect because "lonely" is an adjective that describes a feeling of solitude or sadness. In this sentence, it seems like the intention is to describe that Ms. Malathi is living alone, which should be expressed as "alone in an apartment."

Corrected sentence: "Ms. Malathi is living alone in an apartment."

Using "lonely" to describe the state of living is awkward and not idiomatic in English.

This clarifies that loneliness is an emotional state rather than a physical description of her living situation.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The compensation that the [A] / Government agreed to provide to [B] / the dependents of the [C] / train accident is fairly less [D].

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 10 Dec Shift-2)
solution:
Correct Answer:
D

Explanation:
The error is in segment D. The phrase "fairly less" is grammatically incorrect. Instead, it should be "fairly small" or "relatively less," as "fairly" is not used with "less" in this context.

Corrected sentence:
"The compensation that the Government agreed to provide to the dependents of the train accident is fairly small."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, select ‘No error’ as your answer.
(a) The more it rains,/ (b) worse/ (c) the roads become/ (d) No error

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 10 Dec Shift-3)
solution:
Correct Answer:b

Explanation:
The error lies in part (b) "worse." The sentence is a comparative sentence, and it should use the correct comparative form of "bad." The correct word should be "the worse," not just "worse."

The corrected sentence should be:
"The more it rains, the worse the roads become."

question:
The given sentence contains an error. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
The boy told his mother that he saw the most tall giraffe at the zoo.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 1_Sept_Shift-1)
option_1: The boy told his mother that he saw the more taller giraffe at the zoo.
option_2: The boy told his mother that he saw the most taller giraffe at the zoo.
option_3: The boy told his mother that he saw the tallest giraffe at the zoo.
option_4: The boy told his mother that he saw the most tallest giraffe at the zoo.
solution:
Answer: 3
Solution: The correct sentence is: "The boy told his mother that he saw the tallest giraffe at the zoo."
The word "tallest" is the correct superlative form of "tall".
We do not use “most” or “more” with adjectives that already form their superlative/comparative by adding –er or –est.

Why other options are incorrect:
Option 1 – "more taller" ❌: double comparative (more + taller) is grammatically incorrect.
Option 2 – "most taller" ❌: mixing superlative "most" with comparative "taller" is wrong.
Option 4 – "most tallest" ❌: "tallest" is already a superlative; adding “most” creates a redundancy.

Difficult Word Meaning:
Superlative – the highest degree of comparison (सर्वश्रेष्ठ रूप)
Tallest – the most tall (सबसे लंबा)

question:
The given sentence contains an error. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
He was carefullest while stealing the crown jewels.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 1_Sept_Shift-3)
option_1: He was more careful while stealing the crown jewels.
option_2: He was carefuller while stealing the crown jewels.
option_3: He was most carefuller while stealing the crown jewels.
option_4: He was most careful while stealing the crown jewels.
solution:
Answer: 4
Solution: The correct sentence is: "He was most careful while stealing the crown jewels."

The adjective "careful" is a polysyllabic adjective (more than one syllable), so its superlative form is made using “most”, not by adding “-est”.

  • ❌ "carefullest" is grammatically incorrect.

  • ✅ The correct superlative form is "most careful".

Why other options are incorrect:
Option 1 – more careful ❌: this is the comparative form, used when comparing two things.
Option 2 – carefuller ❌: "carefuller" is not a valid word.
Option 3 – most carefuller ❌: double comparison; grammatically wrong.

Thus, the grammatically correct and appropriate choice is: "He was most careful...".

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
A soothe voice must convey both confidence and intimacy, qualities which can be attributed to a few key components.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 1_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 2
Solution: The error is in the segment "A soothe voice".

The word "soothe" is a verb, but in this sentence, an adjective is required to describe the noun "voice".
The correct adjective form is "soothing", which means calming or comforting (सांत्वनादायक, शांतिपूर्ण).

Correct sentence: A soothing voice must convey both confidence and intimacy, qualities which can be attributed to a few key components.

Why other options are correct:
"convey both confidence" – grammatically and contextually correct.
"which can be" – correctly used relative clause.
"few key components" – correct phrase showing elements being referred to.

So, the error lies in "A soothe voice", and the correct form is "A soothing voice."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
She is / the very ambitious woman / I have ever / come across.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 4 – the very ambitious woman

Correct Sentence: She is the most ambitious woman I have ever come across.

Explanation: The error lies in the phrase "the very ambitious woman". The word "very" is used with positive degree adjectives (e.g., very tall, very smart), but here the clause "I have ever come across" clearly indicates a superlative context. In such cases, we must use "the most" instead of "the very". So, the correct phrase should be "the most ambitious woman".

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The recently hike / in the price of petroleum products / will hit / household budgets severely.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 11 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
option_2: in the price of petroleum products
solution:
Explanation:

The phrase “The recently hike” is grammatically incorrect.

  • “Recently” is an adverb, but it is incorrectly placed before the noun “hike.”

  • What’s needed is an adjective form to describe the noun “hike.”

  • The correct form is: “recent hike” — where “recent” is the adjective.

Part of Speech with the Error:

Adjective/Adverb usage — “recently” (adverb) used in place of “recent” (adjective).

✔️ Correct Sentence:

The recent hike in the price of petroleum products will hit household budgets severely.

✅ Therefore, the segment with the grammatical error is: The recently hike.

question:
The given sentence contains an error. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
This is the eldest standing structure of Chola architecture in India.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 11_Sept_Shift-2)
option_1: This is the most old standing structure of Chola architecture in India.
option_2: This is the more older standing structure of Chola architecture in India.
option_3: This is the oldest standing structure of Chola architecture in India.
option_4: This is the more elder standing structure of Chola architecture in India.
solution:
Answer: (3) This is the oldest standing structure of Chola architecture in India.
Solution:
• The correct superlative form of "old" is "oldest."
• "Eldest" is used for people, not for things or structures.
• Options like "most old," "more older," and "more elder" are grammatically incorrect or redundant.
• Therefore, option (3) correctly rectifies the error by using "oldest."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The blue is a beautiful colour.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 11_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: (1) The blue
Solution:
• The word "blue" is an adjective describing a color and cannot take the definite article "the" alone without a noun.
• The correct phrase should be "Blue is a beautiful colour."
• Other parts ("a," "beautiful colour," "is") are correct.
• Therefore, part (1) contains the error.

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been underlined. One of them contains an error. The underlined parts are given as options with some changes. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
Sohan is t̲h̲e̲ o̲l̲d̲e̲r̲ brother o̲f̲ ̲m̲y̲ b̲e̲s̲t̲ friend.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 12_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
The correct option to rectify the error in the underlined part of the sentence is:

"Sohan is the elder brother of my best friend."

"Elder" is the correct term to use when indicating that one person is older than another.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
My neighbour’s grandson / is only / five month old.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 13 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

⚠️ What’s the error?

  • The phrase "five month old" is incorrect because the word “month” should be plural when referring to more than one.

  • The correct phrase is: “five months old”

✅ Correct sentence:

“My neighbour’s grandson is only five months old.”

🛠️ Grammar Rule:

  • When expressing age, the time unit (month/year) should be plural for numbers greater than one:

  • ✅ One month old

  • ✅ Five months old

✔️ Final Answer: five month old ✅

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
The Dussehra celebrations / in Mysore / this year / are grandest than / in any other part / of the state.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 13 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
solution:
Correct Answer: are grandest than

Solution:
The phrase "are grandest than" is grammatically incorrect. The word "grandest" is the superlative form and should be used with "the", not with "than".
When making a comparison between two or more things, we use the comparative form (grander) with "than", not the superlative.

Correct form: "are grander than"

✅ Correct sentence: The Dussehra celebrations in Mysore this year are grander than in any other part of the state.

Meanings:
grandest – the most magnificent – सबसे भव्य
grander – more magnificent (comparison) – अधिक भव्य
celebrations – events to mark an occasion – उत्सव
state – a region within a country – राज्य

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been underlined. One of them contains an error. The underlined parts are given as options with some changes. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
The weather i̲s̲ c̲o̲l̲d̲ tonight than i̲t̲ w̲a̲s̲ yesterday.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 14_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
The correct option that rectifies the error in the underlined part is colder.

This correction ensures that the comparative form "colder" is used to properly compare the coldness of the weather tonight to that of yesterday.

The corrected sentence would be: "The weather is colder tonight than it was yesterday."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
His worse mistake / was that he had left home / without informing any of us.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-3)
option_2: without informing any of us
option_4: was that he had left home
solution:
Answer:His worse mistake
Explanation:
 The word "worse" is used to compare two bad things (comparative degree). However, in this sentence, we’re not comparing; we are referring to the most bad or biggest mistake.

  • The correct form here is "worst" (superlative degree), not "worse".


✅ Correct usage: "His worst mistake..."

Correct sentence:
"His worst mistake was that he had left home without informing any of us."

Correct option with error:His worse mistake ✅

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
This will be most difficult of / the adjustments we have to make / because we have been used to / spending a lot on guests.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 21 July Shift-3)
option_1: the adjustments we have to make
option_2: spending a lot on guests
option_3: This will be most difficult of
option_4: because we have been used to
solution:
Answer:(3) This will be most difficult of

Solution:
The error is in the phrase “most difficult of”. The correct phrase should be “most difficult of all” or “the most difficult”.
Without "all," the phrase is incomplete and incorrect.

Correct sentence:
This will be the most difficult of the adjustments we have to make...

Word Meanings:

  • Difficult – कठिन

  • Adjustments – समायोजन

  • Used to – अभ्यस्त होना

  • Spending – खर्च करना

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
The food / in the new eatery / is much best than / the one in RK Puram.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 24 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
option_1: the one in RK Puram
solution:
Answer: is much best than
Solution:
• The phrase "much best than" is grammatically incorrect.
• "Best" is a superlative form and should not be used with "much".
• The correct comparative form is "much better than", because we are comparing two things: the food in the new eatery vs. the one in RK Puram.

Correct sentence:
"The food in the new eatery is much better than the one in RK Puram."

Grammar rule:
Use "better" (comparative) when comparing two things.
Use "best" (superlative) when comparing three or more.
Also, "much" can modify comparatives (much better), but not superlatives (much best ❌).

question:
The given sentence contains an error. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
That career competition was the difficultest exam he had ever given.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-2)
option_1: That career competition was the most difficult exam than any he had ever given.
option_2: That career competition was the most difficultest exam he had ever given.
option_3: That career competition was the difficultest exam than any he had ever given.
option_4: That career competition was the most difficult exam he had ever given.
solution:
Answer: 4
Solution: The correct sentence is:
"That career competition was the most difficult exam he had ever given."

Explanation:

  • "Difficultest" is incorrect because the superlative of "difficult" is formed by adding "most" before the adjective, not by adding "-est".

  • The phrase "than any" is unnecessary when using the superlative "most difficult" with "ever".

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Option 1: Incorrect comparative structure ("most difficult exam than any").

  • Option 2: "most difficultest" is a double superlative and incorrect.

  • Option 3: Same errors as above with "difficultest" and "than any".

Therefore, Option 4 is grammatically correct.

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been underlined. One of them contains an error. The underlined parts are given as options with some changes. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
The n̲e̲w̲ ̲r̲e̲s̲t̲a̲u̲r̲a̲n̲t̲ o̲n̲ ̲M̲a̲i̲n̲ ̲S̲t̲r̲e̲e̲t̲ i̲s̲ ̲c̲h̲e̲a̲p̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲n̲ t̲h̲e̲ ̲o̲l̲d̲ ̲o̲n̲e̲.̲ ̲

(SSC MTS 2023 : 5_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: Option 1 – is cheaper than

Solution:

The original sentence is:
"The new restaurant on Main Street is cheap than the old one."

This sentence is grammatically incorrect because of the use of "cheap than". After a comparative structure like "than", we must use the comparative form of the adjective, which is "cheaper", not the base form "cheap".

Correction:

  • ❌ "is cheap than" → incorrect

  • ✅ "is cheaper than" → correct comparative structure

Now examine the options:

  • Option 1 – is cheaper than ✅
    Corrects the comparison grammar. This is the right answer.

  • Option 2 – the older one
    This is grammatically correct, but the original sentence says "the old one", which is acceptable. So this change is not necessary.

  • Option 3 – in Main Street
    "On Main Street" is the correct preposition. So "in" is not a correction, but an error.

  • Option 4 – newer restaurant
    The sentence already uses "new restaurant", which is fine. "Newer" would only be used if comparing two restaurants explicitly.

So, the only actual error is the incorrect comparative form "cheap than", and the correct substitution is:

Option 1 – is cheaper than.

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been underlined. One of them contains an error. The underlined parts are given as options with some changes. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
He i̲s̲ ̲g̲o̲o̲d̲ a̲t̲ ̲p̲l̲a̲y̲i̲n̲g̲ t̲h̲e̲ ̲g̲u̲i̲t̲a̲r̲ t̲h̲a̲n̲ his brother.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 5_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: Option 2 – is better

Solution:

The sentence is:
"He is good at playing the guitar than his brother."

Let’s identify the issue:

  • The phrase “good at playing” is correct when not comparing.

  • But the sentence includes “than his brother”, which is a comparative structure.

  • In comparisons, we should use a comparative adjective, not just "good".

Correct form:

  • ❌ "He is good at playing the guitar than his brother" → Incorrect comparison.

  • ✅ "He is better at playing the guitar than his brother" → Correct.

Analyse the options:

  • Option 1 – in playing ❌
    Incorrect preposition. The correct idiom is “good at playing”.

  • Option 2 – is better ✅
    Corrects the comparative structure. Suitable replacement for "is good".

  • Option 3 – to ❌
    Grammatically incorrect and unrelated to the error.

  • Option 4 – guitar ❌
    The word "guitar" is spelled correctly and used appropriately.

So, the correct rectification is "is better" – Option 2.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Vikram is very stronger than I am.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: Option 2 – very stronger

Solution:

The sentence is:
"Vikram is very stronger than I am."

The error lies in the phrase "very stronger".

Grammar Rule:

  • We do not use "very" with comparative adjectives like stronger.

  • Instead, we use "much", "far", or "a lot" for emphasis with comparatives.

  • Or simply remove "very" altogether.

Correction:

  • ❌ "very stronger"

  • ✅ "much stronger" or just "stronger"

Correct sentence:

"Vikram is stronger than I am."

So, the error is in Option 2 – very stronger.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
In Nepal, the food is more cheaper than in Sri Lanka.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: (2) more cheaper
Solution:
• The phrase "more cheaper" is grammatically incorrect because it is a case of double comparison
• The word "cheaper" is already a comparative form of the adjective "cheap", so using "more" before it is unnecessary and wrong
• You should use either "cheaper" or "more cheap" — but not both together

Correct sentence:
"In Nepal, the food is cheaper than in Sri Lanka."

Grammar Rule:
• Use "more" with adjectives that are longer (usually two syllables or more) → e.g., more beautiful, more interesting
• Use "-er" form with short adjectives → cheaper, faster, taller
• Never use both together (❌ more cheaper)

Therefore, the error is in option (2) more cheaper, and the correction is simply "cheaper" ✅

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains a grammatical error.
 Bobo was / very richer than Jim / as he had illicitly accumulated / all his wealth.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 7 Dec Shift-3)
option_4: as he had illicitly accumulated
solution:
Answer: very richer than Jim

Explanation:

  • The comparative adjective richer already expresses the comparison, so it shouldn’t be modified by very.

  • Correct forms would be much richer than Jim or simply richer than Jim.

  • The other segments are grammatically sound:

  • “Bobo was” – correct subject–verb

  • “as he had illicitly accumulated” – correct use of past perfect and “illicitly” (अनैतिक ढंग से)

  • “all his wealth.” – correct object phrase

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains a grammatical error.
The wedding gown / looked decently / despite being / studded wit jewels.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 9 Dec Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: looked decently

Explanation:
In the sentence, looked is a linking verb describing appearance and must be followed by an adjective, not an adverb. Thus, “looked decently” is incorrect— it should be “looked decent.”

  • Linking verbs (look, feel, seem) pair with adjectives.

  • Adverbs like decently modify actions, not states.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Human activity often / has a negatively effect / on the ecosystem of wetlands.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
option_1: on the ecosystem of wetlands
solution:
The error is in the segment: "has a negatively effect".

  • The word "negatively" is an adverb, but in this context, it is modifying a noun ("effect").

  • To correctly modify a noun, we need an adjective, not an adverb.

  • So, the correct phrase should be: "a negative effect" (where "negative" is an adjective).

Correct Sentence:
Human activity often has a negative effect on the ecosystem of wetlands.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
A ground-breaking discovery has been made / in a deserting quarry near New York, / where researchers have unearthed / the planet's most ancient forest.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
option_1: the planet's most ancient forest.
option_3: in a deserting quarry near New York,
option_4: A ground-breaking discovery has been made
solution:
Segment with error:in a deserting quarry near New York

Explanation:

  • The word "deserting" is incorrect in this context.

  • "Deserting" is the present participle of the verb "to desert", which means to abandon, and is not appropriate for describing a location.

  • The correct adjective should be "deserted" (meaning abandoned) or "desert-like" if referring to a dry area.

Corrected sentence:

"A ground-breaking discovery has been made in a deserted quarry near New York, where researchers have unearthed the planet's most ancient forest."

The rest of the sentence is grammatically correct.

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the option that has the error. If there is no error, select ‘No error’.
Rohit Sharma’s century was very acclaimed in the media.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The segment "very acclaimed" contains a grammatical error.

  • The adjective "acclaimed" is a non-gradable adjective, meaning it already conveys a strong meaning (i.e., highly praised), so it should not be modified by "very".

  • Instead of "very acclaimed", use "widely acclaimed", "highly acclaimed", or simply "acclaimed".

Correct sentence:
"Rohit Sharma’s century was widely acclaimed in the media."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
We have not received some information from our coast guards yet.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Solution:

  • The sentence is:
    "We have not received some information from our coast guards yet."

  • The error lies in the phrase: "some information from"

  • Explanation:

  • When used in negative sentences, we typically use "any" instead of "some".

  • "Some" is generally used in affirmative sentences, while "any" fits naturally with negatives and questions.

  • Therefore, the correct phrase should be: "We have not received any information..."

  • Why the other options are correct:

  • "We have not received" – grammatically correct.

  • "our coast guards yet" – correctly placed and used.

  • "No error" – incorrect because an error exists in the sentence.

Corrected sentence:
"We have not received any information from our coast guards yet."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
Throw of / the old shoes; / nobody will wear / them now.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 4))
solution:
The segment that contains an error is "Throw of".

The correct phrase should be "Throw off", which means to discard or get rid of something.

The sentence would correctly read: "Throw off the old shoes; nobody will wear them now."

So, the answer is "Throw of".

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Don’t go / outside / because it is / raining heavy.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (03-July Shift 3))
solution:
In English grammar, adjectives and adverbs serve different purposes:

  • Adjectives describe or modify nouns. For example: heavy rain (here, "heavy" describes the noun "rain").

  • Adverbs describe or modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. For example: It is raining heavily (here, "heavily" modifies the verb "raining").

In the sentence "Don’t go outside because it is raining heavy," the word "raining" is a verb. To describe how it is raining, we need an adverb, not an adjective. The correct adverb form of "heavy" is "heavily."

Thus, the correct sentence is:

"Don’t go outside because it is raining heavily."

question:
The given sentence is divided into four segments. Select the option that has the segment with a grammatical error.
She forbade / him not / to enter that / room.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.12_09-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct answer: him not

Explanation:

  • The verb "forbade" is correctly followed by the infinitive with "not" before the verb, not before the pronoun.

  • The correct structure is: "She forbade him to enter that room." or "She forbade him from entering that room."

  • Saying "him not to enter" is incorrect.

Correct sentence:
"She forbade him to enter that room."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
His skills in programming / are more superior than / most developers / in the company.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.13_09-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct answer: are more superior than

Explanation:

  • The phrase "more superior than" is incorrect because "superior" is already a comparative adjective, so adding "more" is redundant.

  • The correct phrase should be "are superior to".

  • Other parts of the sentence are grammatically correct.

Correct sentence:
"His skills in programming are superior to most developers in the company."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
The students were diligently / studying for their exams / for weeks before you arrived.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.17_14-Oct_Shift-3)
option_2: for weeks before you arrived
solution:
Correct Answer: The students were diligently

Explanation:

  • The error lies in the placement of the adverb "diligently".

  • In English grammar, adverbs of manner (like diligently) usually come after the verb or verb phrase, not between the auxiliary verb and the main verb.

Incorrect:
"The students were diligently studying..."
Correct:
"The students were studying diligently..."

Let’s verify the rest:

  • "studying for their exams" – correct.

  • "for weeks before you arrived" – correct.

  • "No error" – not applicable as there is an error.

So, the correct answer is: The students were diligently.

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains as error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
He is t̲r̲u̲e̲s̲t̲ to his words.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.18_15-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct Answer:true

Explanation:

  • The sentence is: "He is truest to his words."

  • The error lies in the use of "truest", which is a superlative form.

  • In this context, we’re not comparing him with others but simply describing his quality of being faithful or loyal.

  • The correct word should be "true" (adjective), as in:

  • ✅ "He is true to his words."

Let’s eliminate the other options:

  • Most truly – adverbial; doesn't fit the structure.

  • Truer – comparative; not suitable here.

  • Truly – adverb; would modify a verb, not correct here.

Therefore, the correct replacement is true.

question:
The given sentence is divided into three segments. Select the option that has the segment with a grammatical error. If there is no error, select ‘No error’.
The committee has careful / considered the report which you sent us / and has decided to take action.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.18_15-Oct_Shift-1)
option_2: and has decided to take action.
option_4: considered the report which you sent us
solution:
Correct Answer:The committee has careful

Explanation:

  • The error lies in the phrase "has careful".

  • The verb "has" should be followed by a past participle or adverb, not an adjective like "careful".

  • The correct form is: "has carefully considered", where "carefully" is an adverb modifying the verb "considered".

✅ Correct sentence:
"The committee has carefully considered the report which you sent us and has decided to take action."

Therefore, the segment with the grammatical error is: The committee has careful.

question:
Select the sentence that has a grammatical error.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.19_15-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: There is a man sitting beside cat.
option_2: She saw an excellent episode of the series.
option_3: After a tiring day, I had a cup of coffee with Sudhir.
option_4: She asked an easy question, and I took an hour to crack it.
solution:
Correct Answer: There is a man sitting beside cat.

Explanation:
The sentence is missing an article before "cat".
It should be: "There is a man sitting beside a cat."

All other sentences are grammatically correct.
Hence, the error lies in the first sentence.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Although she is usually / rude with everyone, / she behaved nice / with all of us today.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.2_30-Sep_Shift-2)
option_1: with all of us today
solution:
Correct Answer: she behaved nice

Explanation:
The word "nice" is an adjective, but in this sentence, it should be an adverb modifying the verb "behaved." The correct form is "nicely."

  • Although she is usually – Correct

  • rude with everyone – Correct

  • she behaved nice – Incorrect; should be "she behaved nicely."

  • with all of us today – Correct

So, the segment with the grammatical error is:
"she behaved nice"

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I have lived with my parents / in Mumbai / in a residential flat / yet two years.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.20_15-Oct_Shift-3)
option_2: I have lived with my parents
solution:
Correct Answer: yet two years

Explanation:
The phrase "yet two years" is grammatically incorrect.
The correct expression for duration in this context is "for two years".

Correct sentence: I have lived with my parents in Mumbai in a residential flat for two years.

"Yet" is used to refer to something that hasn't happened up to now (e.g., I haven’t finished yet), not to show duration.
Hence, the error is in "yet two years."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Her decision, / given the complex circumstances, / was too impulsively made.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.21_16-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct Answer: was too impulsively made.

Explanation:
The error is in the phrase "was too impulsively made."
The adverb "impulsively" is awkwardly placed before the past participle "made".
The correct construction should be: "was made too impulsively" – placing the adverb after the verb phrase.

Corrected sentence: Her decision, given the complex circumstances, was made too impulsively.

Part of Speech Note:
"Impulsively" is an adverb, and it should modify the verb "made" in the proper position.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
In addition with / the existing crisis in economy, / the rise of hunger index / is another cause of worry.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.25_17-Oct_Shift-2)
option_2: the rise of hunger index
option_3: the existing crisis in economy
option_4: is another cause of worry
solution:
Answer: In addition with

Explanation:
The phrase "In addition with" is incorrect. The correct phrase is "In addition to" when adding information.

Correct sentence:
"In addition to the existing crisis in economy, the rise of hunger index is another cause of worry."

Other segments are grammatically correct.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The happy and cheerful girls / is always running towards / the ice cream cart in / front of the garden.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.28_18-Oct_Shift-2)
option_2: the happy and cheerful girls
option_3: the ice cream cart in
solution:
Answer: is always running towards

Explanation:
The subject "The happy and cheerful girls" is plural, so the verb must also be plural.

  • The correct verb form is "are always running towards."

  • "Is" is singular and does not agree with the plural subject.

Correct sentence:
"The happy and cheerful girls are always running towards the ice cream cart in front of the garden."

question:
Identify the error in the given sentence.
Ajit got to work earliest than everyone else today.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.28_18-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: earliest than

Explanation:
The correct comparative structure should be "earlier than" instead of "earliest than."

  • Earliest is the superlative form and does not pair with "than."

  • Earlier is the comparative form and correctly pairs with "than."

Correct sentence:
"Ajit got to work earlier than everyone else today."

question:
Select the sentence that has a grammatical error.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.29_18-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: He don't like spicy food.
option_2: They play chess together on weekends.
option_3: She usually walks her dog in the park every morning.
option_4: The train leaves the station at 8:00 a.m. every day.
solution:
Answer: He don't like spicy food.

Explanation:

  • The correct form is "He doesn't like spicy food."

  • "Don't" is used with I, you, we, they.

  • "Doesn't" is used with he, she, it.

Other sentences are grammatically correct.
